Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Lesser Occipital and Greater Auricular Nerve Block for Analgesia in Vestibular Schwannoma Craniotomy

Trial_Design.evidence: In this prospective, double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 62 patients aged 18-64 years were enrolled at Tongji Hospital, China.

Participants.evidence: 62 patients aged 18-64 years were enrolled at Tongji Hospital, China.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either LOGAB with 5 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine (n=31) or normal saline (n=31).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the analgesic efficacy and safety of ultrasound-guided lesser occipital nerve block combined with greater auricular nerve block (LOGAB) in patients undergoing vestibular schwannoma resection via a suboccipital retrosigmoid approach.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the numeric rating scale (NRS) scores at rest and motion within 48 hours post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed in sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, outcome assessors, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 62 patients aged 18-64 years were enrolled at Tongji Hospital, China.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 59 patients were analysed (30 in LOGAB group, 29 in control group) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: NRS scores at rest were significantly lower in the LOGAB group compared to control (mean difference = 1.4, 95% CI 0.9 to 1.9; p=0.002).
